title: Provides that complaints brought against mental health professionals shall be commenced within ten years of the date of the last treatment
summary: Provides that complaints brought against mental health professionals shall be commenced within ten years of the date of the last treatment of the complainant.

memo:
BILL NUMBER:S1720

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend the education law, in relation to the statute of limitations
for professional misconduct for mental health professionals

PURPOSE:
This legislation amends the education law to provide a statute of
limitations of ten years for all complaints of professional
misconduct against mental health professionals licensed under
articles 153, 154 and 163 of the education law. In cases involving
the treatment of children under the age of twenty-one years old, all
complaints of professional misconduct shall be commenced within ten
years after the complainant reaches the age of majority

JUSTIFICATION:
Mental health professionals licensed under Title VIII of the education
law are required to keep all patient records for at least six years.
For non-adult or minor patients, records must be kept until one year
after the age of 21 years (NYCRR EDN §29.2 (3)). A failure to comply
with record keeping requirements constitutes unprofessional conduct
by mental health professionals and can result in a formal
professional misconduct charge.

Currently, there is no statute of limitations for professional
misconduct for these professionals. In light of this fact, mental
health professionals must keep patient records in perpetuity to
protect themselves from any charges of professional misconduct from
former patients that may be brought against them decades after
treatment. This is extremely onerous and burdensome on these
individuals who provide an invaluable service to society by treating
countless patients with mental health illness so that they may remain
productive members of society.

This legislation would appropriately establish a statute of
limitations for mental health professionals that exceeds current
patient record keeping requirements by an additional four years and
thereby eliminate the need for these individuals to maintain patient
records indefinitely.

LEGISLATIVE HISTORY:
2009-10: S.1767
2007-08: S.4155
2006:    S.7396-A

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:
None to the State

EFFECTIVE DATE:
Immediately.
